title: 106_hr3561
content: The Act is titled the "Japanese Imperial Army Disclosure Act" and establishes a working group for Japanese Imperial Army records. The Act establishes definitions for terms like "agency" and "Interagency Group," as well as "Japanese Imperial Army records" related to experimentation and persecution during a specific period. The Act establishes the Japanese Imperial Army Records Interagency Working Group to oversee records related to the Japanese Imperial Army ending in 1948. The Interagency Group is established by the President, with members including the Historian of the Department of State, the Archivist of the United States, and other appointed individuals. The group must hold an initial meeting within 90 days of the Act's enactment to begin its functions. The Interagency Group, established by the President, must locate, inventory, recommend for declassification, and make available to the public all classified Japanese Imperial Army records of the United States within 1 year of the Act's enactment. They must also coordinate with agencies to expedite the release of these records and submit a report to Congress detailing their activities. The Interagency Group and agencies are authorized to receive necessary funding for carrying out the provisions of the Act. SEC. 3. REQUIREMENT OF DISCLOSURE OF RECORDS. The Japanese Imperial Army Records Interagency Working Group is required to release Japanese Imperial Army records, with exceptions for privacy reasons such as personal privacy invasion and national security concerns. The curr_chunk discusses information that, if revealed, could harm national security, military plans, diplomatic relations, and technology within the United States. The curr_chunk outlines exemptions for disclosing information that could impair national security, emergency preparedness plans, or violate international agreements. There is a presumption that public interest is served by disclosure. The curr_chunk discusses the conditions under which exemptions can be applied for disclosing records of the Japanese Imperial Army. The agency head must determine if disclosure would be harmful to a specific interest and report it to Congress. The exemptions for withholding records related to investigations or prosecutions by the Office of Special Investigations of the Department of Justice are subject to the same standard of review as records withheld under section 552(b)(1) of title 5, United States Code. The agency head can only exempt records from release based on the grounds outlined in paragraph (2). The National Security Act of 1947 exemption does not apply to any operational file that is a Japanese Imperial Army record under this Act. SEC. 4. Expedited processing of FOIA requests for Japanese Imperial Army records will be granted to individuals persecuted as described in section 2(a)(3). SEC. 5. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
